remixed_from.author: vik
remixed_from.title: Mendel X Carriage a la Prusa

title: Dual Mendel X Carriage a la Prusa

description.text: This is my second modified Prusa Mendel X Carriage that will fit the standard Mendel X axis. It uses PLA bushings instead of the standard bearings. These now clip in place and have pins on top that locate into generous spaces in the carriage. This allows the user to optionally bond the bushings in place by dropping glue, blu-tak, gum, earwax etc. into each hole. This is designed not to fix to a Prusa Mendel, but to clamp to the Mendel drive belt using the 2 clamps provided in the design. Two pinch extruders http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8830 or one Wade extruder can be fitted to the carriage.

Requires http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2192 if you decide to rebuild under OpenSCAD. Print. Fit X belt clamps with 20mm x M4 screws, washers and nuts. Clip the plastic bushings into place on carriage body. Push 4 x M4 nuts for holding the extruder into the cavities. Warm bushings with hairdryer or blowtorch to avoid fracture during fitting. Push onto X axis rails and leave to cool. Clamp X drive belt on. Clamp on extruder ditto. Once on the rails, it is hard to remove forcibly without breaking the bushings unless you warm them up. Warming the bushings is also beneficial if they're too tight as this will de-stress them.. Works best in PLA (see http://diamondage.co.nz/pla.html ) due to lower friction in the bushings.

this servo tray, for the EMAX ES08MAII servos, is designed to be used in flying wings, for me it was always a major pain, to replace a servo in a flying wing. You can simply glue in this bay into your wing (either epoxy or gorilla glue) and secure the servo with the supplied self tapping screws. In case of a servo failure, simply remove the 2 screws, drop in a new servo, and you're flying again ! 2 Design's available :
  • Open Bottom
  • Closed Bottom with a channel for the servo plug and cable
    • Check the two Picture on How to Cut and Install the Tray

comments.text: I'm slowly putting together a new reel mount for my Up! Mini, based on Emett's gear bearing design. I doubt it's absolutely necessary but it'll be interesting to see if it makes any difference to my prints. The mount will consist of a 1/4" hex rod ( Standard power screw driver fitment ), a pair of modified gear bearings, a fitment for attaching the mount to the printer case and some method of keeping it all on the rod. Watch this space. :-)

author: dee987

description.text:
This may be a derivative of Jetguys http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6184, not sure, but it was definitely inspired by it.
I don't really like bushings so I will slowly be moving to bearings where ever I can. I liked Jetguys idea and it makes good mechanical sense. But one I didn't really want to modify my ToM permanently with the tubes and I would have to pull it apart more to do that. Two I wanted to get bearings on the Z axis. My first thought was to use a linear bearing and it still may go that way. But this seems to be working from my preliminary tests. I haven't done any hi speed tests or anything of the sort. Just a basic cube.
This may be a WIP not sure :) we'll have to see how this one works out and see if there are any improvements. If any one else builds this I would really like to know your results. This was designed for the HBP it won't fit with the ABP.

Print one then mirror on X axis and print another. Attach 2 3x8x3 mm bearings to the two mount points on the bottom of each support. Remove a Z axis rod from the top, remove the lower bushing. Remove the 3 screws holding the bottom plate and using longer bolts, I used 20mm cause I had them laying around. Attach the bracket to the bottom plate. The corner bolt is a bit tricky to install but it goes easy enough. Make sure you use a ball hex wrench though. Replace Z rod and repeat on opposite side. Recalibrate your Z height, as it may have changed the angle of the Z table. Oh I forgot I made the mounting holes a bit small because right now my printer has a problem with printing the holes. So you will have to drill the 3 out. The holes where the bearings mount are intended to be tight so you can thread a bolt into them securely, don't drill those out.

comments.text: I will probably be making some of these. Do they still work properly after 5 months of use?
comments.author: TimCC

comments.text: Well I can say that they are still working fine. But keep in mind i'm not printing on them all day either, or even every day. But i don't see any failures or cracks. I haven't had to change my z home setting so I will assume that there is no fatigue either.
comments.author: TimCC

comments.text: Are the 3x8x3 mm bearings from the Makerbot store?
comments.author: jimcook

comments.text: I actually had purchased some from VXB http://www.vxb.com/http://www.vxb.com/ but some have gotten them from Ebay. I'm not sure if Makerbot sells them or not, but they are not a standard part on the ToM.
comments.author: jimcook

comments.text: This made the Z-Axis travel VERY smooth.  The ABP not fitting is a small issue.  I am thinking of attaching a small stop block to the back of the X Stage that will cause it to stop short of the Y Axis endstop.  Not sure if this is a good idea or not -- sacrificing about 22mm of Y axis travel for the ABP builds.  I guess I need to know how big the bucket of octopi is before I make my decision.  Worst comes to worst, I can always take the supports off.
comments.author: BoyScoutHighTechCamp

comments.text: I will make the modifications for the arch, yeah it was a pretty tight fit. Also because i don't have the ABP I really didn't think about the size. I can make some modifications to the support sizes if you think it is possible, with out weakening it too much.
comments.author: BoyScoutHighTechCamp

comments.text: Great Idea and I like the fact it's printable. The only downside it this will interfere with anyone using the ABP as it sticks out behind the build platform (the long acrylic sides and back roller). I think the tube mod takes less forward area in front of the rods (I was able to dremel the acrylic and still use the ABP without crashing into the tubes-but just barely). It does work just fine though with the HBP only as you have shown. Again, this isn't a flaw of your design, it a problem with space in the bot in the first place.
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Yeah I should have mentioned that I will edit the text above. I don't use the ABP and didn't even think about how it would fit with that. Thanks for the input.
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Still very cool!
comments.author: epideath

comments.text: Very awesome something I will look into doing!

author: ozanbdr

description.text:
3D printed cover for a decora light switch that acts as a emergency stop button. This could be used on a normal light switch or it could be used as a stop button for a printer. The Button in action
https://youtu.be/UITHrjkgVy0

you will need to acquire the hardware for this button 5 6-32 lock nuts
4 6-32 x 1 1/2 machine screws
6 6-32 x 1/2 machine screws
1 6-32 x 3/4 machine screw
1 6-32 x 1 machine screw
2 1/2 long springs
I purchased a 25 count box of 6-32 x 1 1/2 machine screws and then cut them to the correct length
rubber bands will work in place of the springs but springs are preferred
see pictures for placement of the hardware

comments.text:
This is a very clever design, and I would like to incorporate it in my enclosure, but as this design is from 2015, I have some questions:
Are still using the switch?
Has it stood up over time? ie does it still function as desired over this time period?
Is this the latest version?
comments.author: drwatson6

comments.text: I appreciate your interest in this design. The files that are posted are the most up to date version and coresponds with the switch that I have been using approximately biweekly since posting the files. I have had no issues with the switch and it has always worked as desired, this being said, I am unaware of of other people's success. Hopefully this was helpfull and good luck with your enclosure.
comments.author: drwatson6

comments.text: Great. Thanks for the response. I just finished building it. I had to sand down the plate for the two buttons as they didn't move freely. I also had to remove material in the inside of the big button because the connecting arm couldn't get deep enough in to get the bolt holes to line up.

title: Aztec Castle or Temple - Jewelry Container, Storage Box or Lamp

description.text:
This is a temple or scifi castle inspired by aztec architecture.  The inside is hollow to reduce the amount of material used, cut down on printing time and so that one can store items inside the print.  
There is a two piece version that can be used as a storage box for ornaments, jewelry or anything else that would be small enough to fit inside.  
There is a version designed as a lamp, use the two piece lamp base, it will accommodate wires running out the bottom - the light can be rigged inside the hollow of the castle.  
All the versions are in STL and thing format (Makerbot).  
This print looks stunning in natural or white material.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

medium resolution (.2mm layer height)

Infill:

16%

Notes: If you are using transparent or translucent material you might want to set infill to 0% so that the infill pattern is not visible - I haven't tried that yet but will do that for the next print.
Modeled in Modo.

To print a larger model, select the two piece version (base and top). If you have a larger printer and want to print the whole model in one go, then select the one piece version. If you want to print out the version that is designed as a lamp, select the two piece lamp version and the two piece top. You can use the following item for the internal lamp for the castle:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:602016

description.text:
A part to fix a broken lid hinge on an old Sony record player. Recently I got a record player from a garage sale. It works perfectly, except that one of the hinges that holds up the lid was broken. This means that the lid wouldn't stay up on its own.
To solve the problem I modeled the broken part of the hinge and printed it, now it works again.

Start by printing the hinge. When you slice it be sure to turn on full supports so all the parts will print correctly.
Next, disassemble the old hinge by first removing the spring from under a hood in the metal base then sliding the hinge pin out.
Replace the broken part with the freshly printed one, slide the pin back in and re-secure the spring.
For those interested I have also included the NX6 .prt file it was created in.

comments.text: I know this is super old, but is there any chance you also have a design for the other side of the hinge?

title: Replacement spacer for Ikea Ingolf chair

description.text:
I recently noticed that one of my Ikea Ingolf chairs was missing one of the black plastic spacers from its underside. Without this spacer the chair was not held securely together and wobbled.  
It is a simple part so I printed a replacement. In the photos you can see the printed version (yellow) compared with the stock version (black).
Printed in the as-shown orientation with 0.2 mm layer height, 25% infill on a Printrbot LC.

comments.text: Thank you! Chair got loosened last night because this piece is missing. I'm so relieved I don't have to design it myself. I'll post pics after I print.

description.text:
completely re-disigned M2 fan bracket.  
Made it stronger and added the spacing gap needed to keep the bracket off the extruder screws. I also added the proper spacing for the fans for easier assembly and the correct angle for the 50mm fan to put more air down.  
Netfabbed and ready to print.  
Highly recommend an infill of 90 or more for this part.  
ADDED: Version 3 of the bracket can be found in my things.

comments.text: added
comments.author: Hello18

comments.text: I added 2 pics with the 40mm turned off to the right so you can see how it mounts. The pic from the front is home all and there is about 6mm of space between the frame and 50mm fan.

comments.text: needs to be offset to avoid hitting frame when X is home
comments.author: cbachalo

comments.text: I'm still not sure why it would be hitting the frame, is there a way to post a pic from the top and front of the extruder while in the home position?

comments.text: See #13 for X fan mount issue.  Double check your X end stop assembly.  When setup properly there is only 1 mm between fan edge and frame when X is home.  This allows the print head to travel all the way to the edge of the bed.

remixed_from.title: Migbot Prusa i3 X axis Tensioner Upgrade

description.text: This is a revision to jamimr's  x tensioner. I changed it a little to accomodate my pulleys as the slot was too narrow. I also enlarged the screw drive mounting holes and hole for the adjuster screw.

comments.text:
Hello! This is cool design but I found one issue. Holes for the idler pulley aren't in the same position like on original Migbot. Hole here looks centered, while it should be like 4mm offset to the bottom. It looks like it may create an issue in X axis movement - angled belt travel distance is not the same as carriage travel distance. Can you provide cad files or modify it?
Thanks
Victor
comments.author: vfalendysh

comments.text: Good design, I like the Acme rod - it is so smooth. However, I think it is causing a problem for me. The Acme threading is a bit different than the threading of the standard type rod that came with the Migbot. Because of this, I think that when the printer's firmware tells the steppers to move .10 mm, it is actually moving .? mm. Does this make sense? Did you edit the machine's firmware when you moved over to Acme from the rod that came with the unit? If so, can you post those details?
comments.author: AccidentalWisdom

comments.text: Can you upload a STEP file or any other CAD format, so I can modify your design? The Z axis rods don't fit on my Migbot clone.

title: Angled Vertical Charging Stand - Pebble Time

description.text:
As requested by Reddit, this version has an upper plate at 30deg to the base. I don't plan on printing this myself as I prefer the non-angled version, so I can't say if this will work or if the magnets on the Pebble charger are strong enough to hold the watch in place.  
Fairly straight forward vertical stand for the Pebble Time, designed to allow the straps to hang downwards instead of requiring you to feed them through gaps as required in other designs.  
The charging cable is secured into the printed part with a small strip of 3M 03609 VHB tape. The wire easily pushes into the groove, and is also held in place with a few strips of the same VHB. I strongly recommend you pick a place for the stand and affix it there with some Command Adhesive strips between the bottom of the stand and the surface top; the weight of the stand is not sufficient to allow you to just pull the watch off.  
Recommend printing with 0.2mm layer heights at 40 mm/s, 50% infill for structural rigidity. Support needed on the wire channel.

title: tripod - 4 degrees of freedom fixed with one screw

description.text: there is a bunch of tripods in this forum, but no one with the ball design I had in mind. So I created it. The central mount pipe has 4 DOF all fixed by operating one screw as shown in my little demonstration film. The screw squeezes the socket, and the socket the two ball halfs. The design is optimized for printing. I printed mine for use with 10mm aluminium pipes (using 0.5 as scale factor) and with threading. It came out astonishingly good and the ball halfs easily slipped into the socket one after the other. I think one can use it to mount a whole bunch of things: microphones, cameras and webcams, laser pointers and scanners, antennas, lights, ... let me know your applications.

• a tripod with minimum 30° XY freedom, 360° Z freedom and with full linear freedom of the central pipe
  • a customizable design defaulted for 20mm diameter pipes.
  • easy adaptation to your pipes: just scale the thing as a whole
  • a well documented structured code that is easy to understand

• scale factor
  • pipe radii
  • leg angle
  • toggle whether screw is threaded into PLA or a nut is used
  • toggle between assembled and print preview of current design

• OpenSCAD
  • ShortCuts.scad library (sorry for that, but it simplifies programming so much). Description in: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:644830
    • Have fun

title: Froggy: the 3D printed ball-jointed frog doll
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is my first ball-jointed doll. I have always been fascinated by these but shocked at the prices they command. When the excellent Sonia Verdu uploaded her beautiful Robotica, it inspired me to make my own doll for 3D printing. Whilst Froggy is not a derivation of any of her work, I should give Sonia credit, because if I hadn't had her work to refer to, it would have taken much longer to design this frog. I made a prototype of Froggy back in February and took two prints to MRRF, where he generally got a positive response. After MRRF, I went to stay with my cousin and his family in Chicago for a few days, where my two "nieces" gave me detailed feedback on what they would change. I returned home and left Froggy alone whilst I worked on other projects but I eventually returned to him and decided to add in the following features: 1) People will try to pose a doll like a human if it looks even slightly human. The original froggy was designed to move like a frog, so I humanised his proportions and movements. He can sit up and stand by himself. His head twists and is angled like a person's. 2) My mum suggested movable eyes, so I thought I'd see if I could do this. Hooray! I could. 3) He has jointed and posable fingers. Sometimes I just like making things difficult for myself:-) He isn't the easiest model to print and assemble, but I really enjoyed making him. Instructions on how to print and assemble Froggy are here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Froggy-The-3D-printed-ball-jointed-frog-doll/ Froggy has a non-commercial license. If you would like to use him commercially then please contact me beforehand. NOTE: I had missed out chest.stl on my initial upload. This is now present. Sorry for any confusion...
The file eyeball_pupil.stl has been replaced with one which has the correct orientation.
It was suggested I upload a combined and decimated version of the finger files. You can now print a finger at a time and it should take far less time to slice.
Uploaded a new version of finger_middle.stl as the original one was not slicing well in Simplify3D
Please read the instructions here: http://www.southquay3d.com/index.php?route=information/information&information_id=13

comments.text: Not for this doll, but possibly for the next doll I make, where I'll make a point of using open source software (like Blender, for example) that everyone has access to.  Besides which, I was able to learn from Sonia by looking at the STLs alone, so there is really nothing stopping anyone from doing the same with my files.
comments.author: avalero

comments.text: Well not allowing derivatives nobody can take your design as an starting point, which is a pity because it is great.
comments.author: loubie

comments.text: My understanding of non-derivatives license is that someone can't take the actual geometry of my work, change it and publish it.  However, there is nothing to stop someone looking at my files and working out (for example) how a knee joint might be built and then modelling their own. It would be much the same as buying a doll model and seeing how it's put together - i.e using an example to understand the principles.  Ball jointed dolls are designed around some common concepts, there are just differences based on aesthetics and the amount of articulation the designer wants to achieve. I credited Sonia because I used her work as a convenient (and excellent) reference, but I never used any of the geometry). In addition. spent time looking at pictures of dolls on the web to try and work out what I needed to do. I also developed articulation ideas of my own and if people want to use those concepts then that's fine with me.

title: Han Solo Blastech DL-44 conversion parts

description.text: Others have provided similar sets of pieces to convert a Mauser replica into Han Solo's signature blaster. This is simply my take on the thing. Mine is based on an inexpensive, airsoft Mauser that I got on Amazon. Small update: I designed the parts so that I wouldn't have to use supports, which is what led me to split the scope mount and scope vertical rail into two parts that would then be glued back together. This glue joint, by it's very nature, creates a weak point that could break. So, I'm adding a unibody version of the scope mount as an option. I haven't printed one of these myself, so I don't know the best orientation for it, but it will definitely need to be printed with supports. Another update: A month or so ago, I uploaded a new version of the front heatsink. When I did, I completely and utterly failed to give proper credit to the originator of that model, Delphius. My sincerest apologies for this oversight on my part. Delphius's great work can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1245642

All pieces should print best in the orientation provided.   Supports should not be needed.  NOTE:  The heat sink has supports built onto the model that should be removed before attaching.   
Print 2 of the scope top brackets.  
Glue the scope vertical rail to the scope mount.  
Glue the two halves of the scope together and then glue the scope adjustment mount to the top.  The scope adjustment knob and scope rings will stay in place with tension alone.  
Attach the scope horizontal bar to the body of the replica gun by first attaching the the two widest knobs to be used as spacers and mounting points.  Glue or screw these to the replica body, then attach the bar to the mounting points using the knurled knobs and M3 screws.  
Slide the vertical scope rail onto the dovetail, and secure it with the center knob and another m3 screw.  
You'll likely have to cut the barrel of the replica down to receive the barrel extension.  Secure it in place, and attach the flash suppressor, using another M3 screw to hold it in place.  I made the flash hider removable so that I could swap it out with an alternate version that has the end painted orange, should I ever decide to brandish it in public.   
The scope is held into the mount with the top scope brackets and M3 screws (I use M3s for everything).  
The heat sink will need to be glued in place.

comments.text: Hi all, a quick note regarding finding the airsoft to use as a base:  I've been getting them on ebay pretty consistently, usually for less than $12.   Just search for "Mauser C96 Airsoft" or "M32 Airsoft".   As discussed below, be wary of the ones that say "All Metal" or something similar, as they're the 80% smaller ones.   The correctly sized model is visually identifiable by the vac metalized (chrome) rear sight and a black grip screw, whereas the 80% version has the opposite.  I'm attaching some photo references just to help alleviate some of the confusion.

comments.text: I just uploaded a new version of the unibody scope mount that has supports generated by meshmixer.  You're welcome to use this one, but I uploaded it really just to show the orientation I used to print the part.  There's just no way to do it without using supports.  I tried to get around it by splitting the part in two pieces initially, but that created such a weak spot at the connection that I went back to the single piece.  So, to sum up, either print the new version with the supports as is, or print the other one, oriented like the new one, but with your own support material.

comments.text: I'll start by saying awesome job, I'm really looking forward to printing this. If you don't mind I have one small improvement you could consider. The perforated 'cone' at the top of the flash suppressor is very thin. I'll be printing my set at 0.8 scale for the smaller C96 airsoft gun. When I ran the flash suppressor through a few slicing programs they came up with a max shell thickness of one or two using a 0.5mm nozzle. Because of this I'm afraid that the quality of the print will suffer and also that that section of the flash suppressor will be extremely brittle. My personal recommendation would be to thicken that section of the suppressor by 2X or even 3X. That's about it, everything else is awesome.

description.text:
I was playing around in Solidworks and made this Printer test,
Enjoy! ;D
Draw a small 2D design, then use the revolve tool.

I bought fan to add to my extruder barrel cooling duct ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8461 ) and wanted to run it from the same wires that I was previously running to the fan on top of the stepper extruder motor. Since I didn't want to cut the female connectors off of the two fan leads, I decided to design a connector that both pieces could fit into. The STL creates four of these connectors, you'll only need one.

• Print the dual connector piece. Both of my fan connectors fit right into this piece.
  • Then I cut and bent a small paperclip so that it would fit into the red wire connectors and used another section for the black wire connectors.
  • The leads from the motherboard were attached to the appropriate piece of wire.
  • Plug in both female fan connectors.
  • Run both fans simultaneously!

Enjoy! Please post pictures if you print it and say what you are using them for!

author: gerald2015

description.text: Got a broken headphone jack?  Cut it off, solder on a good one and use this customizable mold to create a new end.

Sugru works great for casting ends!
  • Customize, print and sand the mold for a good fit
  • Apply some soapy water to the mold and roughly mold out your jack with sugru.
  • Press the rough mold into the two halves. Use 2 or 3 bolts to ensure it all lines up properly.
  • Use a clamp to press the mold firmly together.
  • Gently open the mold and remove the casting immediately. DO NOT CURE IN THE MOLD. See the notes below.
    • NOTES:
    I had only limited success with allowing the sugru to cure IN the mold. I don't think it can out-gas enough to properly cure. I have since made several more casts of this type using the soapy water The variable names aren't my finest, but are well documented in the .SCAD file with a nice ASCII drawing. Download it and things will be much more clear. The DF MarkDown that Thingiverse uses doesn't have a way of escaping 'special characters' so I can't reproduce the drawings here.

comments.text: Hello could you send me a picture how to solder a four-pole plug?
comments.author: VincentNagler

comments.text:
Try the link below. Double check everything before you cast! Picking apart the sugru is hard work. I have had a lot of luck by first coating the plug with a thin layer of hot melt glue. This makes it stronger and easier to set in the mold.
http://blog.mklec.com/trrs-and-trs-plugs-and-sockets-explained/

description.text: A charging dock for your Apple Watch

Since Apple released WatchOS 2, the watch supports a night stand mode when charging the watch horizontally with the crown on top. This design support this use case. Many other prints emphasize on the vertical use case, which is still fine, but a different use case. Since
Inspired by the Moto 360 Charging Dock.

Works well with the 42mm edition, but 38mm edition should also work just fine. Works fine with the Sport band, but leather and metal bands should also work just fine.  
The cable is feed outside on the bottom with three different angle options for best fitting your use charging use case.
Created with the great Antimony tool.
The printed version photos show the result 60% done. After that my filament feeder broke. I will upload the final result once I repaired the printer.

title: Motor Retainer Set for 29mm Rocket Motors

description.text: Model rocket motor retainer that fits 29mm diameter motors and mounts to the aft end of the motor mount tube, similar to an Estes retainer.  Easier than using nuts & bolts style retainers and allows for motors of different lengths (if body tube length permits).

Male piece is mounted to a motor mount tube with an outer diameter of 1.21" (30.7mm) like the LOC Precision thick-walled tube. The flange on the inside of the male piece is tube insertion stopping point when assembling with epoxy.
After male piece is mounted to the tube, the motor is inserted, and the female piece is screwed on thus holding the motor in place during flight.

comments.text: I can't even tell you how many of these things I'm going to be using.   Started with one to try,  fits perfect,  dimensions look to match the ESTES retainers.   Printing more as we speak.   Seriously useful file here.

author: RSMissimer

description.text: This is an 8mm linear bearing to test Igus part RJZM-01-08 (http://www.igus.com/wpck/3663/drylin_r_rjum_01?C=US&L=en). The outer shell is printed in ABS and the inner sleeve is printed in Igus Iglidur 180-PF Tribo-filament. The Iglidur filament is made specifically to hold up to wear caused by repetitive motion. See here for more info: http://www.igus.eu/wpck/12019/iglidur_TriboFilament?C=DE&L=en

For the shell, I printed in ABS, 30% infill, 0.1mm layer height, 250 C nozzle, 100 C heated bed with a light coat of ABS slurry.  
The insert was printed using the same parameters as above except I used the Igus filament and 100% infill.  
I've included four versions of the sleeve. I've found that at 8mm ID, the sleeve needs a bit of sanding out. For me the 8.3mm ID sleeve fits snugly on an 8mm rod. You may need to experiment depending on your printing conditions.

title: A 3 piece tool set for MakerStudio engineering construction sets

description.text:
This set is for makers using the Maker Studio construction system.
There is a Measuring tool to make sure the holes you make are on center and even. A Remover tool to pry off stuck parts or push rods through holes. And a Gripper tool for grabbing the rods or safely push them through tight holes.
It is printed on a 100 mm square printer bed. I used 6 perimeter and .015 build height. DO NOT change orientation of the parts! They are set for maximum strength  and won't break this way.

title: Airfoil Rocket Fin with Through-the-Wall Tabs

description.text:
Rocket fin with an airfoil cross-section and 5mm through-the-wall fin tabs for a sturdy attachment to the body tube.
The thickest part of the airfoil is 1/3 from the front tip of the fin and maintains the same aspect ratio from its root chord to tip chord.
Please see the multi-view drawing for a better understanding of the overall shape of the fin.

Full sized fin will fit diagonally on a Makerbot Replicator 2 plate (see image) but Makerware will scale it to any desired size.
Slots must be cut into the body tube of the rocket for the fins to properly attach. An epoxy fillet at the base is suggested (see gray line at the base of each fin in the first image).

This is a nice little case for the Geppetto Electronics USB µISP.
It uses 3mm acrylic and 2mm(.08") acrylic.
This case also allows access to the switch on the board. You can find the instructions here: http://www.built-to-spec.com/blog/usb-microisp-case/ If you don't have a laser cutter, you can grab one of these cases from our store here: http://builttospecstore.storenvy.com/products/13521426-usb-isp-case Design made by Thingiverse user RoboLemur.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jxm4Tqwzg1M
Made using Tinkerbot.

I needed a spool holder that fit on my ELFA work station, so I took thing 805833, and thing 196258, and put them together. This is the result. Print with supports. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9U9BCCiCWID

Both my first custom design and first print on my personal printer!  
A case I designed for a power supply tester I made on a 2" protoboard. The base and case are fairly generic, with a hole in front for an LED, back left open for heat sink. The top cover is a little more specific, and fit the adapter that I needed. Held together with 3" 6-32 machine screws.

(4x) 3" 6-32 UNC Machine Screws
(4x) 6-32 Hex Nuts
(4x) Rubber feet When I printed it I had to drill out the screw holes and the hole for the LED, but have since increased the hole sizes. Only actually needed one of these so haven't printed to check the new clearance... if something doesn't fit, grab a drill. Slot for protoboard was also a tight fit, but with a little pressure it will slide into place.

remixed_from.title: New Stronger Hinge for Acrylic Door (Lulzbot Enclosure)

title: Improved Hinges for Lulzbot Mini Enclosure (or any other 3mm panel)

description.text:
This printed Hinge is an update and revision of thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:772303). It uses 1.75mm Filament as hinge pin, has nice strong design with rounded corners, and smooth operation. Has a couple of kerf parameters in the Open SCAD files to adjust the fit, based on how full your printer is printing. The improvements in this revision are a captured pin on one end, to keep a slightly loose hinge pin from migrating down, and an improved hinge radius, for smoother movement right off the printer. It uses a flush mount M3 Flathead machine screw, 10mm length works well with a 3mm panel, and the M3 stress relieving washer thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755320).
This hinge is part of an add-on enclosure for a Lulzbot Mini 3D printer. The other parts are up online, and the entire enclosure is available at: http://drazzticaction.com/products-page-2/3dprinters/lulzbot-acrylic-enclosure/ or Enjoy,
Jim Rasmussen
TabSynth Design Works
Madison, WI
Printed with standard settings. And it works just fine. Requires 4 M3 x10 machine screws, and four nuts, per hinge. Print out the M3 plastic stress relieving washers to use with acrylic doors.

description.text:
I'm debugging my newly built Cupcake CNC, and I wanted a small object that would give me a way to test changes to the bot and to skeinforge. I wanted a simple test that would take as little of my precious ABS as possible. So I created das kleine Testmaenchen, or the little test man. Why in German? Because it sounds more awesome in German. (Thanks to Zaggo for correcting my German)
It's a quick, 2 minute build, and it takes under 1cc of ABS.

Skeinforge it and print it out. I'm not sure if a model of this size needs a raft, but I printed one out anyway because I've been having raft trouble; if you're having cohesion problems you might want to do the same.

description.text: This is harking back to the old direct drive pinch extruder in an attempt to reduce bulk and complexity. Two extruders like this can fit on a single X carriage like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8822 . The stepper does not need to be machined. It uses a single 608 "skate" bearing as the other side of the pinch, and when two extruders face each other a .The stepper shaft is coated with rough material and epoxy (the "No Epoxy" in the title refers to the fact that the PTFE is not epoxied in place). Requires thingiverse.com/thing:2192 if you decide to rebuild under OpenSCAD.

For a brief but adventurous life, you can play with this: The stepper shaft in this one was temporarily surfaced with silicon carbide paper (black wet & dry sandpaper). Scuff the shaft a little with SiC paper then epoxy precisely one layer of coarse SiC paper on. This can be held in place compressively while it cures with heatshrink tubing to ensure an even coating. The paper will disintegrate in use, but the SiC will be well embedded in the epoxy by then.
This works fine, until you encounter your first jam and then it peels the epoxy back to bare metal and you end up cutting notches in the shaft with a Dremel...
The 608 bearing has a small exterior diameter M8 washer between it and the extruder block. A larger washer and M8 nut fit on the outside.
The short screw hole on the little arm takes a nut and M4 x 20mm screw to push the motor into the filament with. Do not neglect the bolt perpendicular to this one. Although it holds nothing it offers significant structural support!
4 off M3 x 25mm screws with washers to suit hold the motor to the extruder block.
The little hole near the filament hole is for screwing connectors down with.
Drill through the lower 2 holes and use 2 woodscrews to hold the PTFE Hot End barrier in place. Warm up the cavity in the extruder if the PTFE hot end is a little too snug.

comments.text: I build it.
comments.author: misan

comments.text: As you can see in the picture two changes were made from Vik's design:
comments.author: misan

comments.text: While torque seemed enough at 1A, that was only true for the first foot of extrusion. So I have to change the StepStick driving the extruder for a Pololu that can handle more current. Right now I have settled at 1.3A that seem to be making my 4.4Kg-cm stepper work without missing steps. Please note my setup is 3mm PLA and 0.5mm extruder. ABS or 0.35mm extruder will require more torque.
comments.author: misan

comments.text: The trick is to use a splined shaft instead of an attached, roughened drivewheel. This is because the spline has a smaller radius and hence a greater mechanical advantage.
comments.author: misan

comments.text: That would be great. At 7mm radius I am not getting enough torque for working faster than 40mm/sec. Maybe a splined shaft with half that radius would get me above 100mm/sec. I'll stay tuned.
comments.author: Guest

description.text: Scratch is a web-based graphical programming system designed to get young people interested in programming. More info: http://scratch.mit.edu/ Since Scratch 2.0 is out and Scratch day is on May 18th, I decided to do a medallion to give away to kids that are interested in programming. There is a small hole if you want to make a necklace or attach it to something like a bookbag. The Purple one was printed as fast as my machine would handle and shows a good bit of lash. Print it a little slower than you usually would print and it should be fine. I used the SVG images of the characters from the MIT site and made bumpmaps to get the 3d shape I wanted. Probably not the best modelling job but it works.
